perturbation.original_text: "AMAG Quality Tasks" means AMAG's quality, testing and release obligations set forth in Section 2.6(b) and in the Quality Agreement; "Annual Product Review Report" means the annual product review report as described in Title 21 of the United States Code of Federal Regulations, Section 211.180(e); "Annual Report" means the annual report as described in Title 21 of the United States Code of Federal Regulations, Section 314.81(b)(2);
perturbation.changed_text: "AMAG Quality Tasks" means AMAG's quality, testing and release obligations set forth in Section 2.6(b) and in the Quality Agreement; "Annual Product Review Report" means the yearly product review report as described in Title 21 of the United States Code of Federal Regulations, Section 211.180(e); "Annual Report" means the yearly report as described in Title 21 of the United States Code of Federal Regulations, Section 314.81(b)(2);
perturbation.explanation: Here, 'Annual' has been changed to 'yearly'. Although they seem identical, legally and practically they are not. Changing 'Annual' to 'yearly' introduces potential ambiguity and contradiction, especially in regulated contexts where 'Annual' has a specific meaning tied to regulatory reporting cycles. The contract uses 'Annual' in other sections, so using 'yearly' creates confusion.

perturbation.original_text: AMAG shall notify Antares within [***] after receipt of the Order Acceptance if such proposed delivery date is unacceptable for AMAG, and in such event, the Parties shall promptly discuss and seek to agree on an alternative delivery date. If AMAG does not respond within such [***] period, the proposed date will be the confirmed delivery date. Antares shall not be obligated to fill any portion of any Purchase Order to the extent the volumes in such Purchase Order exceed the volumes set forth in the most recent Binding Forecast (such excess amount, the "Excess Order").
perturbation.changed_text: AMAG shall notify Antares within [***] after receipt of the Order Acceptance if such proposed delivery date is unacceptable for AMAG, and in such event, the Parties shall promptly discuss and seek to agree on an alternative delivery date. If AMAG does not respond within such [***] timeframe, the proposed date will be the confirmed delivery date. Antares shall not be obligated to fill any portion of any Purchase Order to the extent the volumes in such Purchase Order exceed the volumes set forth in the most recent Binding Forecast (such excess amount, the "Excess Order").
perturbation.explanation: The term 'period' has been changed to 'timeframe'. While seemingly synonymous, consistent use of 'period' throughout the contract establishes a specific meaning. Changing it to 'timeframe' introduces ambiguity, especially if other clauses rely on a precise interpretation of 'period' for calculating deadlines or obligations.

perturbation.original_text: The descriptive headings of this Agreement are for convenience only, and shall be of no force or effect in construing or interpreting any of the provisions of this Agreement. 12.5 Governing Law; Choice of Forum. This Agreement shall be governed by and interpreted in accordance with the substantive laws of the State of New York, without regard to its conflict of law provisions. The Parties agree that the United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods does not apply to this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: The descriptive headings of this Agreement are for convenience only, and shall be of no force or effect in construing or interpreting any of the provisions of this Agreement. 12.5 Governing Law; Choice of Venue. This Agreement shall be governed by and interpreted in accordance with the substantive laws of the State of New York, without regard to its conflict of law provisions. The Parties agree that the United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International Sale of Goods does not apply to this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'Forum' to 'Venue' introduces potential ambiguity and contradiction in legal context. 'Forum' generally refers to any place where legal recourse takes place. While 'Venue' is a term referring to a place where a case is heard. They are slightly different in legal aspects, and changing the term may make the contract ambiguous.
